interconnection.net_metering_details: Arkansas has net metering for systems up to 25 kW residential and 300 kW commercial. 2-to-1 net metering ratio applies (2 kWh generated offsets 1 kWh consumed for systems over certain thresholds). Credits roll over monthly, reconciled annually.
interconnection.fees: Varies by utility; typically minimal for residential systems

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: Arkansas has a solar access law (Act 464 of 2019) that limits HOA restrictions on solar installations. HOAs cannot prohibit solar but may impose reasonable aesthetic requirements.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Historic district review handled locally; some cities like Little Rock and Eureka Springs have active preservation commissions.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: Standard IBC wind load requirements. Design wind speeds typically 90-115 mph.
special_considerations.snow_load_requirements: Moderate snow loads in northern and western mountain areas (10-25 psf ground snow load). Standard structural review applies.

licensing.license_type: Commercial or residential contractor license required plus electrician license; must be or work under a master electrician

notes: Arkansas has seen growing solar adoption with favorable net metering policies, though the 2-to-1 ratio for larger systems reduces the benefit. Entergy Arkansas is the dominant utility. The state has no state solar tax credit. Permitting is handled at the municipal/county level with varying requirements. Rural areas may have less stringent permitting.
